abstract.p: Internet consulting firm ComScore Networks finds shoppers flocked online during holiday season, buying nearly $16 billion worth of goods in November and December; computer hardware led holiday purchases; graph shows buying categories (S)

block.p: Those on the receiving end of holiday gifts are looking sharp this year. Shoppers flocked online during the holiday season, buying nearly $16 billion worth of goods in November and December, according to the Internet consulting firm ComScore Networks.
While that is up 29 percent from 2003, consumers' buying patterns were little altered from other times of the year.

Those on the receiving end of holiday gifts are looking sharp this year. Shoppers flocked online during the holiday season, buying nearly $16 billion worth of goods in November and December, according to the Internet consulting firm ComScore Networks.
While that is up 29 percent from 2003, consumers' buying patterns were little altered from other times of the year.

Computer hardware led all holiday purchases, at $3.9 billion, while clothing and electronic gadgets rounded out the top three. Apparel sales, though, jumped higher than other goods, thanks in part to companies like Sears, Wal-Mart and others rolling out clothing categories online.

According to Shopping.com, of the top 10 selling items, two were game consoles (Xbox and PlayStation), one was an MP3 player (iPod, of course) and seven were digital cameras -- quickly filled, no doubt, with photos of recipients modeling their new clothes.
